title.rendered: MatR: Bon Iver and Bruce Springsteen: AUATC

content.rendered:
Bruce Springsteen appears in this song.

I think.

He’s credited with providing backing vocals, at least. I’ll be darned if I can pick them out though, and I’m usually pretty good at that.

“AUATC” stands for “Ate Up All Their Cake,” and it’s brought to you by Grammy-winning indie-folk band Bon Iver.

Bon Iver was one of the first bands to release new music during the great pandemic of 2020. They issued a benefit single called “PDLIF” (Please Don’t Live in Fear) in April to raise money for COVID relief, and they followed it up with “AUATC” in August.

“AUATC” was another benefit single, in this case more against than for a cause. “AUATC” is decidedly anti-capitalist in theme, and to ensure that the somewhat cryptic lyrics didn’t go over listeners’ heads, the band issued a statement when they released the song.

We are calling attention to the fight against capitalism and our collective participation in its dominant institutions. Bon Iver acknowledges our own position within and use of capitalistic practices. It is with recognition of our privilege that we are fully committed to using our unique platform to challenge and change capitalism within our industry, and far beyond.

The song’s theme apparently resonated with other artists, too–because among the background vocals are the voices of Jenny Lewis, Jenn Wasner, and Bruce Springsteen.

Bruce, of course, has been known to speak out against the excesses and abuses of capitalism from time to time, so it’s not necessarily a surprise that he contributed to the recording. What’s surprising is that none of the prominent guest vocalists are individually discernable.

Presumably that’s by intent, in keeping with the song’s theme. But for hardcore Springsteen fans like us, eager to hear our guy’s contributions stand out, we’ll have to look (and listen) elsewhere.

AUATC
Recorded: 2020
Released: AUATC (single) (August 5, 2020)
Never performed

excerpt.rendered: At the height of the pandemic, Bon Iver enlisted some surprising guest vocalists for their one-off anti-capitalist single.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Meeting Across the River: Bruce Springsteen and Jon Bon Jovi, It’s My Life
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: One night only: Bruce and Jon Bon Jovi perform one of Bon Jovi's oldest and biggest hits.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Meeting Across the River: Jon Bon Jovi and Bruce Springsteen, You Give Love a Bad Name
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: One time only: Bruce and Jon Bon Jovi team up at a benefit show to cover Bon Jovi's first number one hit.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Jon Bon Jovi and Bruce Springsteen: Wanted Dead or Alive
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: One time only: For the first time, Bruce and Jon Bon Jovi join forces for one of Bon Jovi's own songs--a signature one at that.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: December 12
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: Bruce records one of the most beloved, evergreen holiday pop songs ever. Plus: the first "It's My Life," a Hurricane Sandy telethon performance and more.

jetpack-related-posts.title: MatR: Jon Bon Jovi and Bruce Springsteen: Who Says You Can’t Go Home
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: One time only: Bruce joins Jon Bon Jovi on "Who Says You Can't Go Home," a song that sounds like Bruce could have written it himself.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Kingdom of Days: March 21
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: On this date: Bruce wins the Best Original Song Academy Award for "Streets of Philadelphia," plays his first-ever show in Australia, releases the single for "Better Days" and more.
